result.execSummary:
The defendant Michael M Schiessl was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft by Contractor <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 779.02(5).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Huber with standard release conditions.
Concurrent with: 14CM1667 and 14CM2263

miscConds.notes:
Restitution in the amount of $9,137.50 to be paid as a Condition of Probation as follows:  $2,457.50 to C.S. and B.S., $620.00 to M.D. (from Case 14CM1972), $740.00 to J.Z. (from Case 14CM1972), $2,500.00 to J.L. (from read in list), $2,500.00 to D.H. (from read in list) and $320.00 to J.B. (from read in list).
If the lighting fixture exists for M.D., it is to be turned over to the Agent to return to M.D. otherwise defendant to notify Agent and costs will be added to the amount of restitution owed to M.D.

No contact with victims.  Defendant is not to operate or be involved in any contracting work unless employed by a contractor as an employee with no involvement in the business aspect of the job.
Follow through with  AODA treatment, counseling.  No use or possession of alcohol/drug paraphernalia/drugs without a valid prescription . Valid prescriptions to be taken only in the manner they were prescribed.  Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety. Disclose to any physician your drug history/dependency.
DNA Surcharge waived.
DNA Sample waived.
  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

timeConds.notes: Non-working hours with release for Work and Treatment ONLY - To commence FORTHWITH

(2) filed
breakdown of restitution

Defendant Michael M Schiessl in court, in custody, with attorney Mark E. Kershek.   Abbey Nickolie appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 1.  Court finds defendant guilty.  Cases14CM1972 and 15CM147 dismissed and read in to this matter.  Statements by M.D. and S.K.  Defense stipulates to restitution.

Court orders the following:

Count 1:
- 9 months Huber with standard release conditions CONCURRENT with 14CM1667 and 14CM2263. STAYED
- 4 years Probation. 
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- DNA Sample waived
- Restitution in the amount of $9,137.50 to be paid as a Condition of Probation as follows:  $2,457.50 to C.S. and B.S.; $620.00 to M.D.(from case 14CM1972); $740.00 to J.Z.(from case 14CM1972);$2,500.00 to J.L.(from read in list); $2,500.00 to D.H. (from read in list); $320.00 to J.B.(from read in list)
- Conditions of Probation:  Follow through with AODA treatment/counseling.  Maintain absolute sobriety/Random UAs.  No use or possession of alcohol/drug paraphernalia/drugs without a valid prescription.  Valid prescriptions to be taken in the manner they were prescribed.  Disclose to any physician your drug history/dependency.  Defendant is not to operate or be involved in any contracting work unless employed by a contractor as an employee with no involvement in the business aspect of the job.  No contact with any victims.  If the lighting fixture exists for M.D. it is to be turned over to the Agent to return to M.D. otherwise defendant to notify Agent and costs will be added to the amount of restitution owed to M.D.

CONDITION TIME: 6 months - NON WORKING HOURS WITH RELEASE FOR WORK AND TREATMENT ONLY - To commence FORTHWITH.
Plea/sentencing hearing on May 7, 2015 at 11:00 am.
Plea/sentencing hearing on April 28, 2015 at 01:30 pm.
